case_name: State of Bihar v. Bharati Press

facts.text: Appeal filed under Articles 132(1) and 134(1)(c) of the Constitution of India in Case No. 273 of 1951 by the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Case No. 273 of 1951. Appeal under Arts. 132  1  and 134  1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated 13th October 1950 of High Court of Patna by Shearer, Ramaswami and Sarjoo Prosad JJ. in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 220 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Arts. 132  1  and 134  1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated I3th October, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Shearer, Ramaswami and Sarjoo Prosad JJ.  in Miscella

facts.text: Respondent was the keeper of Bharati Press at Purulia at all relevant times.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was the keeper at all relevant times of the Bharati Press at Purulia, A pamphlet under the heading Sangram was printed at the said press

facts.text: Pamphlet under heading 'Sangram' printed at Bharati Press.

anchor.surface_text: of the Bharati Press at Purulia, A pamphlet under the heading Sangram was printed at the said press and is alleged to have been circulated

facts.text: Pamphlet alleged to have been circulated in town of Purulia in district of Manbhum.

anchor.surface_text: printed at the said press and is alleged to have been circulated in the town of Purulia in the district of Manbhum. The Government of Bihar companysidered

facts.text: Government of Bihar considered pamphlet contained objectionable matter under section 4(1) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bihar companysidered that the pamphlet companytained objectionable matter of the nature described under section 4  1  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act and required the press to furnish security

facts.text: Government required press to furnish security of Rs. 2000 under section 3(3) of the Act by 19th September 1949.

anchor.surface_text: section 4  1  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act and required the press to furnish security in the sum of Rs. 2,000, under section 3 3  of the Act by the 19th September, 1949.

facts.text: On 26th September 1949, respondent applied to High Court under section 23 to set aside the order.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th September, 1949, the respondent applied to the High Court under section 23 for setting aside the above order. This application was allowed

facts.text: High Court allowed respondent's application by majority; Shearer J. dissented.

anchor.surface_text: the above order. This application was allowed by the majority of the Judges companystituting the Bench. Shearer J. was of the view that the application should be dismissed.

facts.text: High Court held pamphlet came within mischief of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reached the companyclusion that the pamphlet did companye within the mischief of the Act.

facts.text: Sarjoo Prosad J. (with Ramaswami J.) held section 4(1)(a) repugnant to Constitution and void.

anchor.surface_text: Sarjoo Prosad J., with whom Ramaswami J. companycurred, on a companystruction of the decisions of this Court in Romesh Thapar The State of Madras 1 , and Brij Bhushan V. The State of Delhi 2 ,

facts.text: Shearer J. held pamphlet was seditious libel and section 4(1)(a) not void.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Shearer, however, held that the pamphlet was a seditious libel and that there was numberhing in the two decisions of the Supreme Court

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 1952 May 26.

anchor.surface_text: K. Mitra  K. Dayal, with him , for the appellant. Basant Chandra Ghosh and Arun Chandra Mitra for the respondent. 1952. May 26.

facts.text: Supreme Court held section 4(1)(a) constitutional and within Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that speeches or expressions on the part of an individual which incite to or encourage the companymission of violent crimes, such as murder, cannot but be matters which would undermine the security of the State and companye within the ambit of a law sanctioned by article. 19 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held pamphlet does not fall within section 4(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: its judgment has to be maintained as it is also in error in holding that the pamphlet in question fell within the mischief of section4  1  a  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act.

facts.text: Pamphlet written in high-flown Bengali language with demagogic claptrap and poetic flourish.

anchor.surface_text: The document is written in high-flown Bengali language and companytains a good deal of demagogic claptrap with some pretence to poetic flourish.

facts.text: High Court passages interpreted as contemplating bloody revolution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the document offended against the provisions of section 4 1  a  inasmuch as certain parts of it companytemplate a bloody and violent revolution

facts.text: No evidence connecting pamphlet with any agitation or movement in locality.

anchor.surface_text: Their is numberevidence whatsoever for companynecting this pamphlet with any agitation or movement at the time it was written in that locality.

facts.text: Pamphlet contains empty slogans with no particular meaning.

anchor.surface_text: I have read the writing several times and I think that Mr. Ghosh is right when he says that the pamphlet companytains merely empty slogans, carrying numberparticular meaning

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with no order as to costs.

holdings.text: Section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act is constitutional and falls within the permissible restrictions under Article 19(2) as it deals with matters undermining the security of the State.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that speeches or expressions on the part of an individual which incite to or encourage the commission of violent crimes, such as murder, cannot but be matters which would undermine the security of the State and come within the ambit of a law sanctioned by article. 19 2  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words inciting or encouraging violent crimes like murder undermine security of State, directly within Art 19(2) exception.

holdings.text: The decisions in Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan do not compel holding Section 4(1)(a) void, as they concern public order not security of the State.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, Shearer J. was right in the view that there is nothing in the two decisions of this Court which bears directly or indirectly on the point at issue in the present case and that both Sarjoo Prosad and Ramaswami JJ. were in error in holding that these deci- sions were conclusive on the question of the invalidity of clauses  a  and  b  of section 4  1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior cases as dealing with broader public order restrictions, unlike specific incitement to violence here.

holdings.text: High Court erred in holding Section 4(1)(a) repugnant to Constitution; it is valid.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government has succeeded in its contention that sec- tion 4  1   a  of the Act is constitutional and that was the real ground on which it came to this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly upholds constitutionality post-distinguishing precedents and applying Art 19(2).

holdings.text: The amendment to Article 19(2) with retrospective operation is not repugnant to Article 20.

anchor.surface_text: This contention is untenable. The respondent is alleged to have violated the provisions of section 4 1  a  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act which was a law in force in the year 1949 when the offending pamphlet was published.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No ex post facto offence created; section valid law in 1949; no conviction involved.

holdings.text: The pamphlet does not contain words falling within Section 4(1)(a); High Court erred in holding it did.

anchor.surface_text: Though, as I have said above, the High Court is in error in the finding that the provisions of section ,4 1  a   1  1950 S.C.R594, of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act are repugnant to the Constitution, its judgment has to be maintained as it is also in error in holding that the pamphlet in question fell within the mischief of section4  1  a  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pamphlet contains empty slogans, no incitement; High Court misread.

holdings.text: Pamphlet does not fall within Section 4(1)(a) when considered as a whole; merely empty slogans without tendency to incite violence.

anchor.surface_text: In order to determine whether a particular document falls within the ambit section 4 1 , the writing has to be considered as a whole and in a fair and free and liberal spirit, not dwelling too much upon isolated passages or upon a strong word here and there, and an endeavour should be made to gather the general effect which the whole composition would have on the mind of the public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Holistic assessment: abstract rhetoric, no context of agitation, ineffective on educated readers; distinguishes Badri Narain.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed, no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that I would dismiss the appeal but in the circumstances would make no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Maintains High Court judgment on facts despite error on law; circumstances warrant no costs.

precedents.citation: Romesh Thapar The State of Madras 1

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions on freedom of speech for maintaining public order beyond security of the State are unconstitutional under Article 19(2)
precedents.cited_holding: unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation under clause 2 of article 19

precedents.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions on freedom of speech for public order are outside Article 19(2) unless limited to security of State

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thapars case 1  was whether the impugned Act  Madras Maintenance Public Order Act, XXIII of 1949  in so far as it purported by section 9  1-A  to authorise the Provincial Government for the purpose of securing the public safety and the maintenance of public order

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 9(1-A) of Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act authorizes restrictions for public safety or public order, which is wider than security of State

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thalbars case 1  given on the constitutionality of section 9 1-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act has no relevancy for deciding the constitutionality of the provisions of section 4 1  a  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Decision on constitutionality of section 9(1-A) of Madras Act has no bearing on section 4(1)(a) of Press Act

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thapars judgment 1  it was observed as follows -- We are therefore of opinion that unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Law restricting speech must be solely against undermining security of State to fall under Art 19(2)
precedents.cited_holding: We are therefore of opinion that unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation under clause 2 of article although the restrictions which it seeks to impose may have been conceived generally in the interests of public order.

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thapars case 1  could easily have been avoided as it was avoided by Shearer J. who in very emphatic terms said as follows- I have read and re-read the judgments of the Supreme Court, and I can find nothing in them myself which bear directly on the point at issue

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Deduction from the case that incitement to murder through press is immune is incorrect

precedents.citation: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar 1

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar 1 , that though the pamphlet in question uses extravagant language and there is in it the usual crude emotional appeal which is the stock-in-trade of the demagogue as well as a blundering and ineffective attempt to ape the poets, that is all,

precedents.case_name: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar
precedents.cited_proposition: Extravagant language and emotional appeal in pamphlet does not incite to violence in normal circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: though the pamphlet in question uses extravagant language and there is in it the usual crude emotional appeal which is the stock-in-trade of the demagogue as well as a blundering and ineffective attempt to ape the poets, that is all, and there is nothing more in it. The time is long past when writings of this kind can in normal circumstances excite people to commit crimes of violence or murder or tend to excite anybody to commit acts of violence.

precedents.citation: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Govermnent 2

anchor.surface_text: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Govermnent 2 . The learned Chief Justice therein held that in order to show that certain words fall under section 4  1   a  it is not necessary to show that the words tend to incite or to encourage the commission of a particular offence or offences

precedents.case_name: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Government
precedents.cited_proposition: Not necessary to prove tendency to incite specific offence; sufficient for cognizable offences involving violence in general
precedents.cited_holding: in order to show that certain words fall under section 4(1)(a) it is not necessary to show that the words tend to incite or to encourage the commission of a particular offence or offences and that it is sufficient if they tend to incite to or to encourage the commission of cognizable offences of violence in general.

anchor.surface_text: Harkrishan Singh v. Emperor 1 , the use of such words as appear in this document creates no impression on the mind of any reasonable reader. That case dealt with clause  d  of section 4  1 , but the principle underlying it also applies to the construction of writings which are alleged to fall under section 4  1   a .

precedents.cited_proposition: Use of certain words creates no impression on the mind of any reasonable reader
